importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The initial investigation into Sell My Timeshare (SMT) began in summer 2016, when a personal finance journalist learned about a potential scam targeting timeshare owners.
The BBC Scotland Investigates programme exposing SMT's fraudulent practices was broadcast on 24 October 2016, leading to increased public awareness and prompting police investigation.
During the first wave of the Covid-19 pandemic, police reported 19 arrests related to SMT, marking a turning point in the legal action against the company and its operatives.
The final criminal proceedings concluded on 19 October 2025, with 14 individuals convicted of conspiracy to defraud in a £28 million timeshare fraud scheme.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline spans nearly a decade, from initial discovery in 2016 to the final convictions in 2025, highlighting the prolonged nature of the fraud and the investigative efforts over time.

keyTakeAways: A £28 million timeshare fraud involving over 3,500 victims, mostly aged between 60 and 80, was exposed through secret BBC filming.
The company Sell My Timeshare (SMT) operated a 'bait-and-switch' scam, convincing victims to pay large upfront fees for fake 'Monster Rewards' with no real resale value.
Victims were led to believe they would be freed from their timeshare contracts and receive financial returns, but instead were left with useless credits and still bound by decades-old contracts.
Mark Rowe, the top executive, received a seven-and-a-half year jail sentence; his wife Nicola received a two-year suspended sentence for money laundering.
Nine years after the initial BBC investigation, 14 people were convicted in a series of trials at Southwark Crown Court, following a long period of legal uncertainty and public pressure.
The BBC’s secret filming provided critical evidence, leading to police investigation and eventual criminal prosecution, demonstrating the power of investigative journalism in exposing fraud.
The fraud was enabled by the popularity of timeshares in the 1980s and 1990s, with many elderly individuals inheriting or being locked into contracts they could no longer afford or use.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A £28 million timeshare fraud targeting over 3,500 elderly victims—mostly aged 60 to 80—was uncovered through secret filming by BBC Scotland Investigates in 2016. The company Sell My Timeshare (SMT) deceived victims by promoting a fake 'Monster Rewards' system that promised financial freedom and contract exit, but instead led them to pay large upfront fees for worthless credits. The fraud, which relied on high-pressure sales tactics and a 'bait-and-switch' model, went undetected for nearly a decade. After the BBC broadcast its investigation, police launched an inquiry, and over the next nine years, 14 individuals were convicted, including Mark Rowe, who received a seven-and-a-half year sentence, and his wife Nicola, who received a two-year suspended sentence for money laundering. The case underscores the importance of investigative journalism in holding fraudulent companies accountable and demonstrates how vulnerable elderly individuals can be exploited through complex financial schemes. The Crown Prosecution Service will now pursue recovery of stolen funds.
title: How BBC secret filming exposed a £28m timeshare fraud
